subject: Re: Junit support for non-standard distributed applications
msgSnippet: Mike, Thanks for your answer and your highlighting of the mock object approach. ... network.  The ... tests use ... decoupled ... very ... Actually, the
messageBody:
Mike,

Thanks for your answer and your highlighting of the mock object
approach.

> Conventional wisdom says to use mock objects to simulate the
network. The
> client tests use mock objects to simulate the server; the server
tests use
> mock objects to simulate the client. The client and server stay
decoupled
> and can be developed concurrently by the team. These tests get run
very
> frequently and they don't take long to run.


Actually, the component I'm testing is not that big that it requires
separate teams for the client and server sides. Rather, I'm working
on a distributed system in which processes often alternatively play
the role of client and servers. My goal is to perform functionnal
test of the component which provides support for communication among
processes.

More precisely, I need to exercise the network problems that can
occur (which happen to behave differently based on which operating
system the component is running on, albeit the program is written in
Java), the potential threading problems (such as contention,
deadlocks and other safety problems).

As such, I believe the approach of mock objects is not so beneficial
in my case, because it would require much effort to simulate complex
external behaviors while still not exercizing some conditions that I
encounter in a production environment.

I agree I'm trying to use JUnit for functional tests rather than unit
tests for which it was designed. The reason I'm currently doing this
is that the Junit execution environment is convenient and well
integrated into our Java-base development process: Junit is
integrated into ANT and cruisecontrol, the two tools supporting
automatic build environment including automatic test execution,
collection of logs, analysis of test results and notification of test
failures.

Does anyone know an alternative to the Junit framework (i.e. a better
approach) to support automated functional tests that include more
than one process (and possibly more than one computer). The goal
still being to run these tests "continuously" and to reduce manual
tasks to a minimum in order to detect introduced bugs as soon as
possible?

Thanks,

Guillaume.

--- In junit@y..., Mike Clark <mike@c...> wrote:
>
> Conventional wisdom says to use mock objects to simulate the
network. The
> client tests use mock objects to simulate the server; the server
tests use
> mock objects to simulate the client. The client and server stay
decoupled
> and can be developed concurrently by the team. These tests get run
very
> frequently and they don't take long to run.
>
> On a less frequent basis, and possibly taking more time to run,
other tests
> using the "real" objects are run for end-to-end testing. Ideally,
the only
> difference is that the mock objects are dynamically removed from
the tests by
> plugging in a new factory.
